Succession may very well be one of the greatest tv shows of all time!

It's a premise that tells the story of power and dynasty, a story that's been told time and time again since the beginning of time and the beginning of Shakespeare. Yet, Succession takes that idea and puts it into a modern day narrative, subjectively changing the story and shedding a completely new light on the classic tale.

It's dark, evil and witty but it also has its moments of warmth and harmony.

Ultimately Succession is a tragedy, as the writers have stated, and it was always intended to be a tragedy. Sad and gloomy but carrying enough essence to tell such a raw and complex tale in a format that is somewhat controversial. The classic shaky camera gimmick mix with the most realistic and dramatic script you'll ever hear, gives a sense of pride and purpose. And left with all these unanswered thoughts and questions. And when It's all over it really leaves you with a wondering "what do I do now?"

But at the end of the day Succession started as a simplistic slice of life story, and ended all the same. Because life is unpredictable and doesn't always end the way you planned it.

If you haven't garnered up the urge to watch Succession, I highly recommend you try. Yes, it can be a little bit slow durning the first 2 seasons, but you really learn to love all the characters because of it. And once you become fully invested in the show, it will easily become one of the best forms of entertainment you can have, and there's no going back after that.

I liked the first season because it was telling a clever joke and I proudly "got it": rich people cannot personify their wealth/fame/etc. The kids want to be Daddy, Daddy wants the kids to really be him (instead of faking it) so they can inherit the kingdom. Both of those things are impossible because "Daddy" is a fantasy. They all hate each other because they're trying to live out the same impossible fantasy, except this particular fantasy demands that they also ruin each other's roleplay. Everyone incl Brian Cox believes they're running an actual empire and plays out their roles as pretenders fighting for the throne, with life and death stakes. But it's just a media corp, an entertainment/propaganda/culture factory same as any other, operationally integrated with the state and not even trying to hide it (see Alan MacLeod). And Brian Cox is just an old rich a-hole whose hell is watching his insufferable failchildren's antics in silent, bemused despair as he hobbles out of life.

It began as a decent satire of modern life in general, not rich people specifically. The "decadent lifestyles of the rich and famous" aspect of it was supposed to be the hook, as well as the setup for playing the suffering of these characters for laughs. And it was funny. What is a joke after all? Something absurd and out-of-place irrupting into the mundane social world, throwing it into sharp relief, showing us how stupid and pointless it is. The rich kids will stay rich no matter who ends up running the company. But they want to be the one... really effing badly. They want to be Daddy. Because it's something to do, something that seems less pointless and futile than regular life. It might turn out to be a fantasy, the essence of which is even more pathetic than real life. So what? We'll play.

It should go without saying that all of this is far more applicable to middle-class people - the kind who watch Succession - than the offspring of our reptilian overlords, who have the means to both feel like and be regarded as genuinely decent people who are trying to help. Unfortunately the show forgets that from season 2 onwards, becoming a parody of itself.

From that point on it turned into an epic drama coldly calculated to pander to the demographic that vicariously enjoys portrayals of wealth but have seen too much Jon Stewart not to also simultaneously feel that oh-so-familiar WASP cocktail of guilt and moral vanity. A highbrow soap opera. The weird stunted delivery of fake corporate jargon and florid cussing is now supposed to reflect the characters' insecurities and self-esteem issues, as opposed to the overproduction of communication (see Baudrillard, 'The Ecstasy of Communication). These rich people with their town cars, amply hedged portfolios and outrageously expensive rehabs *are just like us.* The show portrays them harshly but fairly, and mediates those immense gaps of net worth with its sensitive, therapeutic study of the human *blah blahdee blah blerrrgh*. Instead of being the medium for lampooning the soul-crushing banality of life in terminally dysfunctional capitalist civilization, the "realistic" billionaire failson lifestyle reflects the most pleasant version of it back to us, making us feel valid and seen.

On the surface Succession is decent enough. We've got a fairly high production value, acting ranging from good to outstanding, passable writing, and initially the dialogue feels tangible. The characters start off as interesting, if for nothing else because they live and move in circumstances that most of us will never experience. The show dazzles us with a look into a world that is extremely opulent and outrageoulsy decadent.

As we progress, however, the show does become somewhat repetitive. It's the same power struggle, for the same stakes, with the same players back-stabbing each other again and again. In the fourth season stakes are raised as we veer into a US presidential election, but it is still framed from the perspective of the Roy family and their corporate schemes.

For me, the show stumbles primarily on two fronts. Firstly, the main characters are irredeemably awful people. They're vapid, immature, greedy, self-centered, unpleasant and at times outright evil. We can't in good conscience root for any of them to come through, and whenever they do succeed we're left wishing they hadn't.

Secondly, Succession drops the ball on showing the real world consequences of how these terrible characters act. People who are laid off by the hundreds over a Zoom call? Never heard from again. Victims of abuse? A few minutes of screentime in a single episode and then gone forever. Political protestors? Merely faceless sign-holding crowds with no discernable agenda of their own.

It is a major flaw that the story is told exclusively from the point of view of the Roy family and their minions. We only ever learn about their motivations, and everyone else exist simply as pawns or obstacles in the Roy family plots and schemes. This one-two punch of irredeemable main characters, and no external view or opposition that we can empathize with leaves the viewer nowhere to go and no-one to relate to.

It's a shame, because there was potential here to tell a compelling story about power, influence and corruption. We could have had the perspective of DOJ prosecutors, SEC watch-dogs, a corporate whistleblower, laid off employees strugling after being sacked, or any number of servants traumatized by working for the Roys. What we get instead is really just a four seasons long showcase of how awful and decadent rich people can be.

Actors are.good, but the screenplay is horrible.

The characters are shallow. Not even in the worst family business people would make decisions with no information. Everything in this series looks like a shouting contest, like one of those old pirate movies where swordfights were actually won by talking the opponent.

There was so much potential, but directors messed up. It's slow. Very slow. It's like if "This is us" was narrated by Samuel L. Jackson.

Back to characters shallowness... They are unidimensional. We.arent told why they think and act like they do. The worst of them is Roman, who is always in the high ground, but there isn't any explanation on where his power come from.

Of course it's information, leverage over other people because he knows something that can be used against opponents, but he actually doesn't have anything. Every battle is won by the character with the faultiest mouth.

In the real world, a company like that would never have reached its current state, with so many incompetent individuals ahead of it. It's very, very unlikely that the whole plot is even plausible.

The first three season were pretty alright, I'd give them a solid 7 but season 4 kind of destroys it all.

Every episode is the same. Endless conversations consisting of half sentences,allusions and buzzwords without any substance. It is as if the writers themselves don't know where the show is going. After Logan's death the show is as headless as the company in the series.

Succession is a series that catches your attention from the first 20 seconds of the first chapter where Kendall is mentally preparing to enter a world where he has always wanted to climb, which is the CEO of Waystar, from the moment he comes out from the car you capture the vibe of the series and the friction that the brothers will have throughout the series to replace their father and take charge of his legacy as the head of the company.

The performances, the settings, the music, and the script are perfect, and I think the complexity of the characters is excellent in all areas, The series is deserving of winning all the awards and in my opinion, it should be in the top of the best series of all time, on a par with Breaking Bad, The Sopranos, The Wire, among others without a doubt entering the discussion.

Bravo to the producers and all the people involved in this masterpiece.
